ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Vocal technique and stylistic elements of opera

To learn how to think about phrasing and incorporating different elements simultaneously, to make decisions when there are different directions that are all plausible, to analyse how to bring contrast and variety.
Learning new repertoire and skills on violin
I furthered my knowledge of classical piano performance, with a particular focus on French music and Beethoven.
I improved my oboe playing and reed making

I became a better flutist! I gained a ton of knowledge about flute playing and understanding how my own body relates to my playing and what I need to work on to become a more refined musician. I learned a ton of repertoire, too, which I really appreciate.
This semester, lessons helped me prepare for my senior recital and an upcoming concerto engagement in July.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I enjoyed working with professor Yang this semester, as I did last semester.
I had a great experience with lessons this year. No complaints!
For a semester with thirteen weeks of classes, the minimum number of lessons should be twelve, not ten.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely take this course if you are an undergraduate musician looking to improve your skills! Even if you get paired with a grad student, they are kind, helpful, and want you to succeed. I think you also become more connected with the School of Music.
These are independent lessons, so I feel that this question doesn't quite apply... but yea I guess I'd recommend lessons to anyone who wants to take music seriously at Yale.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in continuing their musical studies at the graduate or professional level.
